content_1: .  Health officials are confirming that a four-year-old boy died of H5N1 on December 6, 2012, after coming in contact with dead, infected fowl near his home in the West Java District of Bogor.  Indonesia has been hit particularly hard with the deadly virus with a total of 160 deaths this year alone.  It is unclear if the boy was infected with the new strain of HPAI H5N1 (clade 2.3.2) that was first found in Indonesia in September of last year, but as of a week ago, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, the director of disease control and public health at the Health Ministry, said that the new clade had not infected any Indonesians at that time.While the source of the outbreak has not been confirmed, officials believe the virus may have been brought in through imported ducks.  Officials are concerned that the H5N1 virus may have the potential to mutate which would affect countries worldwide.
content_2: .  The World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed three new human cases of H5N1 since the start of the year, two of them being fatal, in the southeastern Takeo province and in central Kampong Speu province of Cambodia.  The victims, a 15-year-old girl and a 35-year-old man, died after being hospitalized with bird flu.  An eight-month-old boy was also treated and survived.  Last year, Cambodia reported three cases of H5N1, all of them fatal.
